summary: Hairy cell leukemia (HCL) is an uncommon hematological malignancy characterized by the accumulation of abnormal B lymphocytes, known as 'hairy cells', in the bone marrow, spleen, and lymph nodes. These abnormal cells interfere with the production of normal blood cells, leading to various complications. While HCL has an indolent course, patients frequently relapse, but with treatment, life expectancy is generally comparable to the general population.
risk_factors: Male sex (HCL is more common in men)
Farming and gardening (correlates with increased risk in some studies)
Exposure to herbicides (potential risk factor extrapolated from other B-cell leukemias/lymphomas)
symptoms: Infections (due to low white blood cell count)
Fatigue (due to low red blood cell count)
Easy bleeding (due to low platelet count)
diagnosis: Complete blood count (CBC) showing low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets
Blood smear examination for hairy cells
Flow cytometry (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD11c, CD25, CD103, FMC7 positive)
Annexin A1 and BRAF V600E mutant protein testing
treatments: Watchful waiting (for asymptomatic patients without significant cytopenia)
Splenectomy (when other therapies fail and spleen has large disease burden)
Filgrastim (to stimulate white blood cell production)
